subject: Re: [junit] How to automate the testcases!
msgSnippet: Vladimir, I was interested about the idea that JUnit might not be the best tool for testing negative test cases - could you elaborate somewhat for me please. I
messageBody:
Vladimir,

I was interested about the idea that JUnit might not be the best tool for testing
negative test cases - could you elaborate somewhat for me please. I don't quite
see what your're driving at.

Thanks,

Toby

Vladimir Bossicard wrote:

> > I want to test a library containing more than 1000 classes and
> > lots of methods.
>
> I'm sure you don't 'want' but 'have to' test this library :-)
>
> Let's not mention that JUnit is primilarly entended for programmers and not QAs
> (no offense, I just want to say that if QAs are the ones starting to use JUnit,
> something's wrong in the project).
>
> In your place, I would go to your manager and expose the fact that testing
> 1,000 classes will take you months if not years. If he wants to ship in two
> years, fine... but I bet it's not what he wants.
>
> I can't imagine that the developers spend all their time writing code without
> some kind of testing. Chances are that some test code has been written (just
> pray that developers haven't only used 'println') so try to reuse their code
> into JUnit tests and (even better) try to convince your manager to let the
> developers do this. You can then run a code coverage tool to have a look where
> the code has not been tested.
>
> If you want to do negative testing (since it's a library, it must be pretty
> solid) JUnit may not be the best tool for this. But you can write some
> extensions that test that a class is not crashing.
>
> -Vladimir
